I think it'd be quite valuable to preserve the fact that a one-line message break is the same height as a paragraph break, and I don't see a technical reason why the changes we have deployed here should need to change that -- we've always had a blue box and previously were able to make this work, and actually the current blue box is thinner than the original.

It seems like an implementation bug. Further, if you look closely, the blue box isn't centered properly around 1-line messages in this currently deployed version (there's more space above the text than below, which can be visually distracting) -- so that's probably a (related) bug.

To talk about the philosophy here: A lot of the time, one is posting a series of thoughts on something, each in their own paragraph, and if nobody else is posting messages, we want it to feel like your decisions about when to hit enter and continue in a next message can be based on editorial considerations -- things like whether this message is already a complete thought that you'd like folks to be able to emoji react to and your next paragraph is going to be an independent thought, or if you want to let others see what you've written so far as you write the rest to provide a better real-time experience for them, etc., without changing materially the visual experience of reading your series of paragraphs.

Having slightly different spaces also just looks visually less nice -- it can be distracting to see a series of paragraphs that have mixed/choppy spacing. (Every time we regress this, we start getting a slow stream of bug reports "these paragraph breaks look funny", and I think there's a reason for that ... and I even remember some folks wanting to do things like edit messages to copy/paste the later ones into the first one and then delete the rest to get the paragraph spacing they want, which seems like a bad outcome).

I asked several folks who were complaining about the blue box changes in the Recurse Center community for more extended feedback; reposting here without names or screenshots (which contain a bunch of other data from their community):

I'm on the light theme and (another user)'s description matches my experience.

I first noticed the Zulip new look because something felt off. Within seconds I realized I wasn't aware of what message I currently have selected.

Since these changes were introduced, I have been feeling aware of the effort of visually locating the currently selected message every time I use Zulip (I use it multiple times a day). Prior to this update, finding the currently selected message was effortless -- I wasn't aware I was even doing that, and I don't recall how the selected message used to be visually indicated because it worked pretty well and I had never paid attention to how it was indicated.

Currently, the color of the title bars of threads is where my eyes fixate on immediately, then I start visually searching for the selected message. Previously, my eyes would fixate immediately on the currently selected message.

From another user:

I'm on dark mode. I tend to find the title bars distracting, they're given a lot of visual weight by their relatively saturated backgrounds. I do like how they're colored based on the stream's key color, which makes it easy to pick out streams from a list of messages when you're searching or looking at drafts.

And from yet another:

I'm mostly able to find where I am by blindly using the up or down arrows to change the focused message until it causes the screen to scroll, but that is annoying, and still requires me to look carefully at the screen until I can find the one with the extra border.

All the screenshots featured the light theme, and I kinda agree with them that it's a bit tricky to pick out the colors. So I think we should consider whether adjusting the shade in the light theme to have higher contrast would be an improvement.

I think the other direction we could take if we want to adjust the product for this feedback is a "2px wide blue box" accessibility option. I would turn it on myself, since I really value it standing out visually, and I think it might be important to have something like that for accessibility for folks with poor vision even if we felt it was visible enough for most users.

I'm a day-theme user, and I personally love the new blue box. I can still find it pretty easily and I appreciate that it's a subtle effect. But I can definitely relate to some of the above feedback. I find it a little hard sometimes to see the blue box, and I wouldn't object to going back to 2px. I would probably make the effort to turn on the setting if it was an accessibility setting.

I have this crazy hypothesis about usability that if you bother to create a visual effect, people should actually be able to see it. Zulip has all these places where you can barely see icons, or not even see them at all, and then every time something is selected (with the notable exception of the gear menu, which is perfect IMHO), the shade is like 2% darker than the other shade.

Yeah I think it's also very possibly a thing that may depend on your monitor; I can imagine some monitors having issues.

As a final note, the background color changes that we have deployed here change the background that the blue box is on top of in a way that significantly increases contrast, so it's very possible the situation will improve once we deploy this.
Actually, I'm not sure that it actually does; it might just be that it looks like it does because of the contrast with the grey nearby.

And Yes, the bars are bright and colorful, but we change them per feedback that they are not colorful enough... We can dim them a bit back:

function getRecipientBarColor({ color = "#000000", darkMode = false }) {
  return colord(darkMode ? "#000000" : "#f9f9f9").mix(color, darkMode ? 0.38 : 0.22).toHex();
}

Personally I don't agree with the user who thinks the bars are a problem, I think they are misdiagnosing the main issue that for folks who are heavy keyboard users and thus whose usage patterns depend on the blue box, the current colors are too subtle.
But I also think for users who are not heavy keyboard users, the thinner blue box is considerably nicer.
Which is why I started thinking in the settings direction.
From a practical standpoint, moving to having a null state with no focused message is not trivial logically; a bunch of behavior depends on it.
And I think would not be popular with keyboard heavy users. We could make whether the blue box is always visible be a setting, possibly.

My advice here is to just ride this out a bit. I don't want to completely dismiss the RC feedback, but I think people are just expressing natural resistance to change. The current blue box is clearly visible to my 53-year-old eyes. I would avoid any radical changes here and just ping those RC people a couple months from now.
